[Where is the action happening]: The action occurs within the skeletal system, specifically in bones, where bone remodeling is disrupted, leading to osteoporosis and increased fracture risk in MS patients.

[Main point]: The text discusses the side effects of antimalarial drugs chloroquine and primaquine, particularly focusing on their impact on patients with vivax malaria in Brazil. It highlights the frequency of symptoms before and after treatment, emphasizing the importance of assessing side effects in endemic areas.

[Why is it happening]: Antimalarial drugs like chloroquine and primaquine can cause various side effects, including gastrointestinal issues, hemolysis, and neurological symptoms, which can affect treatment adherence and patient outcomes.

[Who is involved]: The study involves 50 people with vivax malaria, 28 men, and 22 women, aged between 7 and 68 years, living in the urban area of the municipality of Mncio Lima, Brazil.

[When is the action happening]: The action happens before and after the administration of antimalarial treatment, specifically focusing on the period between 3 and 5 days after the start of medication.

[Where is the action happening]: The action takes place in the urban area of the municipality of Mncio Lima, located in the western part of the Brazilian Amazon, in the state of Acre, Brazil.

[Main point]: The study examines the effects of combining alpha-blocker tamsulosin and antimuscarinic agent solifenacin on erectile function in patients with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
[Why is it happening]: The research aims to disclose the common pathophysiology between LUTS and erectile dysfunction (ED) and to investigate whether the concurrent administration of these medications can improve sexual function in patients with BPH and ED.
[Who is involved]: Male patients aged 40 years or older with concurrent LUTS/BPH and ED are enrolled in the study.
[When is the action happening]: The study is conducted over a 3-month period.
[Where is the action happening]: The study takes place in a clinical setting, focusing on patients' improvement in LUTS and sexual function after the treatment regimen.

[Main point]: The main point of the text is that specific microRNAs (miRNAs) play a crucial role in the development and progression of cancer, acting as oncogenes or tumor suppressors. These miRNAs can affect the expression of proteins involved in cancer pathways such as apoptosis, migration, and metastasis, making them promising biomarkers for several types of cancer. The text specifically focuses on the miR-200 family and its role in epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT), a process that enables cancer cells to become more motile and metastatic.

[Why is it happening?]: MiRNAs, including the miR-200 family, are involved in the regulation of gene expression. They can either enhance or suppress the expression of specific genes, influencing various cellular processes. In the context of cancer, the miR-200 family is known to repress the expression of ZEB1 and ZEB2, which are associated with EMT. This repression helps maintain the epithelial cell characteristics, including polarity and the expression of E-cadherin, which is crucial for cell-cell adhesion and can negatively affect migration and invasion.

[Who is involved?]: The main actors in this process are specific miRNAs, particularly the miR-200 family, and transcription factors such as ZEB1, ZEB2, Twist, Snail, and Slug. These factors are involved in the regulation of gene expression and the EMT process. Cells, especially those undergoing EMT, are also central to this process.

[When is the action happening?]: The action described in the text is happening during the initiation and progression of cancer, specifically during the EMT process. This process is thought to occur during tumor progression, enabling cancer cells to become more motile and thus more metastatic.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the context of cancer cells, particularly in tissues such as the endometrium, breast, and ovary. The text also discusses the role of miRNAs in the epithelial to mesenchymal transition, a process that occurs during development and is reactivated in cancer cells.

[Main point]: The transobturator approach for treating female stress urinary incontinence through midurethral sling (MUS) placement was first described by Delorme to potentially prevent complications associated with the retropubic MUS placement. A similar transobturator passage utilizing an inside-out approach was later described by de Leval, aiming to further reduce potential injury to the urethra and bladder. A recent meta-analysis found similar cure rates between the three most commonly used surgical approaches for treating stress urinary incontinence, namely the retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator MUS procedures.

[Why is it happening]: The transobturator approach was developed to potentially prevent complications associated with the retropubic MUS placement, such as injury to the urethra and bladder. The inside-out approach was introduced to further reduce the risk of such injuries.

[Who is involved]: The main individuals involved are surgeons who perform the transobturator MUS procedures, patients who undergo the treatment for stress urinary incontinence, and researchers who conduct studies on the anatomical trajectories and safety of these procedures.

[When is the action happening]: The action is happening over a period of time, starting from the initial description of the transobturator approach by Delorme in 2001, followed by the introduction of the inside-out approach by de Leval in 2003, and continuing with the development of new techniques and studies on the anatomical trajectories and safety of these procedures.

[Where is the action happening]: The action is happening in the context of surgical procedures performed in hospitals or clinics, and in the research laboratories where studies on the anatomical trajectories and safety of the transobturator MUS procedures are conducted.

[Main point]: The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 is being post-legislative scrutinized to assess its effectiveness and identify areas for improvement in the new PCET Bill.

[Why it's happening]: The scrutiny aims to evaluate the implementation of the 2015 Act and determine whether it has fulfilled all the Government's objectives, identify weaknesses, and consider whether national outcomes should be set through legislation for institutions receiving public funding. It also looks at the level of ambition in the Act, the balance between institutional autonomy and national priorities, and the adequacy of HEFCW's powers of intervention.

[Who is involved]: The scrutiny involves the Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, and Huw Morris, the director of the skills, higher education, and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government. It also includes the Children, Young People and Education Committee, and stakeholders such as HEFCW, universities, and the University and College Union.

[When is the action happening]: The post-legislative scrutiny is ongoing, with the committee meeting on this topic on September 24, 2019.

[Where is the action happening]: The action takes place in the Senedd, the Welsh Parliament, where the committee holds its meetings.

[Main point]: The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 is being post-legislative scrutinized to assess its effectiveness and identify areas for improvement in the context of the current education landscape and government priorities.

[Why it is happening]: The scrutiny aims to evaluate the Act's fulfillment of its strategic aims, the current alignment with national outcomes, and the adequacy of its regulatory framework, particularly in relation to institutional autonomy, private providers, fee and access plans, and quality assurance. It also seeks to consider how the Act can be better aligned with the proposed Post-Compulsory Education and Training (PCET) Bill.

[Who is involved]: The scrutiny involves the Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, and Huw Morris, the director of the skills, higher education, and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government. The Children, Young People and Education Committee is leading the post-legislative scrutiny process.

[When is the action happening]: The post-legislative scrutiny is ongoing, with the committee meeting to discuss the Act's implementation and gather evidence from stakeholders. The committee is also considering the feedback from the Act's implementation and the evolving education sector to inform the development of the PCET Bill.

[Where is the action happening]: The scrutiny is taking place in the context of the Welsh education system, with a focus on the Higher Education sector in Wales. Meetings and discussions are held in the Assembly offices in Colwyn Bay and through video conferencing, as well as in the Senedd (Welsh Parliament).

[Main point]: The Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 is being post-legislative scrutinized to assess its effectiveness and determine if it needs to be amended or replaced.

[Why it is happening]: The scrutiny aims to evaluate the implementation of the Act and identify any weaknesses or areas for improvement, particularly in relation to the objectives, institutional autonomy, private providers, fee and access plans, and quality assurance. This will inform the development of new legislation for tertiary education.

[Who is involved]: The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, are participating in the post-legislative scrutiny session.

[When the action is happening]: The post-legislative scrutiny session is taking place on the morning of the document's date, which is not specified.

[Where is the action happening]: The action is happening across Wales, with a focus on providing support and alternative arrangements for children in specific categories, such as those in need of free school meals, vulnerable children, and children of key workers.

[Main point]: The main point is the discussion on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill, which aims to remove the legal defense of reasonable punishment for parents in Wales.

[Why is it happening]: The bill is happening because there is a need for clarity in the law regarding the rights of children and to align the legislation with international standards, particularly the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. There is also a desire to prevent potential harm to children and to support a cultural shift towards understanding that children's rights should be upheld.

[Who is involved]: The discussion involves representatives from the Association of Directors of Social Services (Sally Jenkins), the Association of Directors of Education Wales (Alastair Birch), and the Welsh Local Government Association (Councillor Huw David). They are providing insights on the effectiveness of current laws, the impact on children, and the need for clarity and resources for implementation.

[When is the action happening]: The action is happening during a scrutiny session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee on June 18, 2019.

[Where is the action happening]: The action is happening in a public meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee in Wales.

[Main point]: The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to remove the legal defense of reasonable punishment for parents in Wales.

[Why is it happening?]: The current law has been criticized by the United Nations for allowing the defense of reasonable punishment, which the rights of the child should be upheld. The bill seeks to clarify and strengthen the rights of children by removing this defense.

[Who is involved?]: The Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), the Association of Directors of Education Wales (ADEW), and the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) are involved in supporting the bill. They represent children's services, education, and local government in Wales.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is happening during the scrutiny process of the bill by the Children, Young People and Education Committee of the Welsh Assembly. The committee is hearing from witnesses and taking evidence until the bill is passed.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is taking place in the National Assembly for Wales, specifically in the committee room where the Children, Young People and Education Committee is holding its meetings to discuss and scrutinize the bill.
